hints: The main character in a story.
The central figure with whom the audience is meant to sympathize.
Often drives the plot forward.
The character who opposes the main character.
Creates conflict in the story.
Opposite of the protagonist.
A figure of speech that directly compares two unlike things.
States one thing is another without using 'like' or 'as'.
Example: 'The world is a stage'.
A figure of speech that compares two different things.
Uses the words 'like' or 'as'.
Example: 'She is as strong as an ox'.
The repetition of the same sound at the beginning of words.
A literary device commonly used in poetry.
Example: 'Peter Piper picked a peck'.
Giving human qualities to inanimate objects or animals.
Example: 'The wind howled'.
A comma used after the second-to-last item in a list.
Also known as a serial comma.
Example: 'The flags are red, white, and blue'.
A fictional prose narrative of book length.
A long work of fiction.
Examples include 'To Kill a Mockingbird' or '1984'.
Literary work in which special intensity is given to the expression of feelings and ideas.
Uses rhythm and verse.
Often features stanzas and rhyme.
A type of poem with 14 lines.
Usually written in iambic pentameter.
Shakespeare wrote many of these.
A Japanese poetic form.
Consists of three phrases with a 5, 7, 5 syllable structure.
Often about nature.
A literary genre written to be performed on a stage.
Consists of plays.
A form of theater.
An account of someone's life written by someone else.
An account of someone's life written by that person.
Literature in the form of prose, especially novels, that describes imaginary events and people.
Prose writing that is based on facts, real events, and real people.
Examples include biographies and history books.
The central idea or message of a literary work.
A recurring subject or idea.
The author's underlying message.
The sequence of events in a story.
The action that makes up the narrative.
The time and place of a story.
Includes the geographical location and historical period.
The writer's attitude toward the subject matter or audience.
Can be formal, informal, serious, or humorous.
The atmosphere or feeling created in a literary work.
How the reader feels when reading the text.
The repetition of similar sounds in the final stressed syllables.
A common device in poetry.
Example: 'cat' and 'hat'.
The pattern of stressed and unstressed syllables in a line of poetry.
A type of metric line used in traditional English poetry.
Consists of ten syllables with alternating stressed and unstressed beats.
An account of imaginary or real people and events told for entertainment.
A narrative.
A spoken or written account of connected events.
A story.
A distinct section of a piece of writing.
Indicated by a new line or indentation.
A set of words that is complete in itself.
Expresses a statement, question, or command.
A single distinct meaningful element of speech or writing.
A story, poem, or picture that can be interpreted to reveal a hidden meaning.
A deeper moral or political meaning.
The use of objects or ideas to represent something else.
A deeper meaning beyond the literal.
A literary device in which a statement's meaning is the opposite of its literal meaning.
The use of humor, irony, or exaggeration to expose and criticize people's stupidity or vices.
A literary genre.
An imitation of the style of a particular writer or genre.
Often with deliberate exaggeration for comic effect.
A literary work in the form of a series of documents.
Letters, diary entries, etc.
An interruption in a narrative to show an event that happened earlier.
A hint of what is to come later in the story.
A suspenseful ending to a chapter or episode.
Leaves the reader in suspense.
A joke exploiting the different possible meanings of a word.
A play on words.
A word that imitates the natural sounds of a thing.
Example: 'buzz', 'wham'.
Exaggerated statements or claims not meant to be taken literally.
Example: 'I'm so hungry I could eat a horse'.
The presentation of something as being smaller, worse, or less important than it actually is.
A category of literary composition.
Examples are fiction, non-fiction, poetry, and drama.
A technique a writer uses to produce a special effect in their writing.
The perspective from which a story is told.
Can be first person or third person.
Narrator is a character in the story.
Uses 'I' and 'we'.
Narrator is not a character in the story.
Uses 'he', 'she', 'it', 'they'.
A type of third person point of view.
The narrator knows all thoughts and feelings of all characters.
A type of third person point of view.
The narrator only knows one character's thoughts and feelings.
A person, animal, or imaginary creature in a literary work.
An unexpected turn in the plot of a narrative.
The part of a plot that builds suspense toward the climax.
Events between the exposition and climax.
The part of a plot that occurs after the climax.
The events leading to the resolution.
The turning point of the story.
The moment of greatest suspense or emotional intensity.
The end of the story.
The part of the plot where the main conflict is resolved.
Conversation between characters.
A speech made by a character alone on stage.
Reveals inner thoughts and feelings.
A long speech by one character in a play or movie.
A section or speech at the end of a book or play.
Serves as a conclusion.
A separate introductory section of a literary work.
A long narrative poem telling of a hero's deeds.
Examples include 'The Odyssey' and 'The Iliad'.
A fictional prose narrative that is shorter than a novel but longer than a short story.
A brief work of fiction.
Can usually be read in one sitting.
A genre of drama where a hero suffers a downfall.
Ends in sorrow or disaster.
A genre of drama that is lighthearted.
Usually has a happy ending.
A genre of fiction in which a detective or other character solves a puzzle or crime.
A genre of imaginative fiction involving magic and other supernatural elements.
A genre of fiction based on imagined future scientific or technological advances.
A literary genre that focuses on a loving relationship between two or more characters.
A genre of fiction intended to frighten, scare, or disgust readers.
Pertaining to the life of a person.
A type of non-fiction.
Of or relating to poetry.
Possessing the qualities of poetry.
Written or spoken language in its ordinary form.
Without metrical structure.
Writing arranged with a metrical rhythm.
Often having a rhyme.
Opposite of prose.
The activity of telling or writing stories.
The study and evaluation of literary works.
A writer of a book, article, or report.
The person who writes a story.
The person who tells the story.
The voice of a poem.
The person or group for whom a writer writes.
The intended reader.
A person, object, or idea that represents something else.
Visually descriptive or figurative language.
Appeals to the five senses.
A recurring subject, theme, or idea in a literary work.
Repetition of the sound of a vowel in nonrhyming stressed syllables.
Example: 'The rain in Spain falls mainly on the plain'.
The recurrence of similar sounds, especially consonants.
Example: 'The ship has sailed to the far-off shores'.
A part is made to represent the whole.
Example: 'All hands on deck'.
A word is replaced by another word or idea with which it is closely associated.
Example: 'The crown' for a king.
A mild or indirect word substituted for one considered too harsh or blunt.
Example: 'Passed away' for 'died'.
Language that uses words in ways that deviate from their literal meaning.
Includes metaphor and simile.
Language that means exactly what it says.
A form of poetry that tells a story.
A short poem that expresses personal feelings or emotions.
A poem in which one or more characters speak.
Relating to prose that describes imaginary events and people.
Relating to prose that is based on facts and real events.
A long, planned statement in writing or spoken form.
A set of books or other works that are connected.
A book, document, or piece of music written by hand rather than typed or printed.
A person or company that prepares and issues books for public sale.
A person who is in charge of a newspaper, magazine, or book.
A person who prepares written material for publication.
To read and correct mistakes in a written text before it is published.
The analysis and judgment of a literary work.
The process of examining a text to understand its meaning and techniques.
The circumstances that form the setting for an event or statement.
Helps to understand the full meaning of a text.
A conclusion reached on the basis of evidence and reasoning.
A guess based on the text.
A proposed explanation made on the basis of limited evidence as a starting point for further investigation.
A statement or theory that is put forward as a premise to be maintained or proved.
A brief summary of a research article, thesis, or literary work.
A list of the parts of a book or document.
Organized in the order in which the parts appear.
A list of the books or other sources consulted in preparing a work.
A quotation from or reference to a book, paper, or author.
Used in a scholarly work.
An added bit of information at the bottom of a page.
An alphabetical list of terms relating to a specific subject.
Usually found at the end of a book.
An alphabetical list of names, subjects, etc., with page numbers where they are mentioned.
A group of authors who agree on literary goals and techniques.
Examples include Romanticism and Realism.
A literary movement of the 18th and 19th centuries.
Emphasized emotion and individualism.
A literary movement that attempts to represent subject matter truthfully.
Avoids artificial, idealized, or implausible styles.
A literary movement that arose during the early 20th century.
Characterized by a self-conscious break with traditional ways of writing.
A late 20th-century literary movement.
Characterized by skepticism and a rejection of grand narratives.
A literary period during the reign of Queen Victoria.
Included works by Dickens and Eliot.
A literary period from the 5th to the 15th centuries.
Included works like 'Beowulf'.
A literary period from the 14th to the 17th centuries.
Known for Shakespeare and Cervantes.
A literary theme that explores the relationship between colonizer and colonized.
A literary theme that analyzes how gender roles are presented.
A literary theory that focuses on class struggle.
A literary theory that uses psychology to interpret texts.
A literary theory that challenges traditional interpretations of a text.
A literary theory that analyzes literature as a system of signs.
The theory and methodology of interpretation, especially of literary texts.
The art of effective or persuasive speaking or writing.
A style of writing used in research papers and scholarly publications.
A noun that refers to an idea, quality, or condition rather than a physical object.
A noun that refers to a physical object that can be perceived by the senses.
A word that expresses an action or a state of being.
A word that describes a noun.
A word that describes a verb or another adjective.
The way a sentence is put together.
The use of marks such as commas and periods in writing.
The rules for forming words and sentences.
The arrangement of words and phrases to create well-formed sentences.
The body of words used in a particular language.
The way in which a writer writes.
The author's unique voice.
The feeling or atmosphere that the writer creates for the reader.
The writer's attitude toward the subject.
An idea or feeling that a word invokes in addition to its literal meaning.
The literal or primary meaning of a word.
An indirect or subtle reference to a person or thing.
Placing two things close together with contrasting effect.
A statement that seems self-contradictory but contains a deeper truth.
A figure of speech where two opposite ideas are joined.
Example: 'jumbo shrimp'.
A remark or passage in a play that is intended to be heard by the audience but not by other characters.
A long speech expressing the thoughts of a character alone on stage.
When the audience knows something that the characters do not.
When the opposite of what is expected happens.
When a speaker says one thing but means the opposite.
A quality that evokes pity or sadness.
An appeal to logic or reason.
An appeal to credibility or character.
A religious song or poem of praise.
A lyric poem, typically addressed to a particular subject.
A poem of serious reflection, typically a lament for the dead.
A poem or song narrating a story in short stanzas.
A short, clever, and often witty saying or poem.
A speech or piece of writing praising someone or something highly, typically someone who has just died.
Informal words or phrases used by a particular group of people.
A phrase or expression whose meaning cannot be understood from the ordinary meanings of the words in it.
A type of performance poetry.
Often includes elements of rap, storytelling, and theater.
Poetry that does not have a regular meter or rhyme scheme.
Poetry written in unrhymed iambic pentameter.
The chronological series of events that a protagonist undergoes.
The beginning of a story that introduces the characters, setting, and basic situation.
The event that sets the main conflict into motion.
The final part of a play, movie, or narrative in which the strands of the plot are drawn together.
The resolution of the story.
A secondary plot in a story.
Runs parallel to the main plot.
A story within a story.
An example is 'Frankenstein'.
An interruption in the narrative that presents events that will occur in the future.
A typical character, action, or situation that seems to represent universal patterns of human nature.
The main character in a story, often possessing admirable qualities.
A character who contrasts with another character to highlight their qualities.
When the narrator's personal feelings or opinions affect the way they tell the story.
The structure or organization of a literary work.
Examples include novels, poems, and plays.
Fiction written to fit into a particular category, such as science fiction or mystery.
A genre of fiction set in the past.
Combines historical fact with fictional elements.
The freedom to depart from the facts of a matter or from the conventional rules of language when writing.
An adjective or descriptive phrase expressing a quality characteristic of the person or thing mentioned.
The final action that completes the unraveling of the plot in a drama.
The tragic resolution of a tragedy.
A fatal flaw leading to the downfall of a tragic hero.
The process of releasing, and thereby providing relief from, strong or repressed emotions.
A poem in the form of a speech by an imagined person.
An utterance considered as an action.
Fiction that is considered to have high artistic quality.
Fiction written to appeal to a broad audience and sell well.
A group of literary works that are considered to be the most important and influential.
A group of sonnets thematically linked.
An imitation of the style of a particular writer, with deliberate exaggeration for comic effect.
A genre of literature that deals with rural life in an idealized way.
Using humor, irony, or exaggeration to expose and criticize people's stupidity or vices.
A short story, typically with animals as characters, conveying a moral.
A story originating in popular culture, typically passed on by word of mouth.
A traditional story sometimes popularly regarded as historical but unauthenticated.
A traditional story, especially one concerning the early history of a people or explaining a natural or social phenomenon.
A short and amusing or interesting story about a real incident or person.
A concise statement that expresses a general truth or principle.
A novel told through the medium of letters or other documents.
Narration from the 'I' point of view.
A narrator who knows all.
A narrative technique that presents the thoughts and feelings of a character as they occur.
A character's inner thoughts, spoken aloud or written.
Words like 'he said' or 'she replied' that identify the speaker.
The underlying meaning of a text.
The unspoken thoughts and motives of a character.
The final part of a play, movie, or narrative in which the strands of the plot are drawn together.
A short quotation or saying at the beginning of a book or chapter.
Objects or ideas that stand for something else.
Recurring ideas or elements in a literary work.
An expression designed to call something to mind without mentioning it explicitly.
An indirect or passing reference.
Relating to drama or the performance of plays.
Not real; existing only in the imagination.
A quality of fiction.
The activity of putting words on paper or on a screen.
The activity of interpreting written words.
The ability to read and write.
Written works, especially those considered of superior or lasting artistic merit.
A simple story used to illustrate a moral or spiritual lesson.
The highest point in the development of something.
The elevation of someone to divine status.
Excessive pride or self-confidence that leads to a downfall.
Concerning the writing, study, or content of literature.
A poet officially appointed by a government to compose poems for special events.
An award for achievements in newspaper, magazine and online journalism, literature, and musical composition.
An international award for outstanding work in various fields, including literature.
A mild or indirect word or expression substituted for one considered to be too harsh or blunt.
A statement that seems self-contradictory but expresses a possible truth.
The use of humor, irony, or exaggeration to expose and criticize people's stupidity or vices.
The general character or attitude of a place, piece of writing, situation, etc.
A temporary state of mind or feeling.
The emotional atmosphere of a literary work.
The use of descriptive language to create a vivid picture in the reader's mind.
The central topic or subject of a literary work.
A struggle between opposing forces.
The main problem in a story.
The process by which the writer reveals the personality of a character.
The time and place in which the story takes place.
The main events of a play, novel, movie, or similar work.
A story or account of events, experiences, or the like.
Written or spoken language in its ordinary form, without metrical structure.
Literary work in which special intensity is given to the expression of feelings and ideas by the use of distinctive style and rhythm.
A literary genre that is meant to be performed on a stage.
English playwright and poet widely regarded as the greatest writer in the English language.
English novelist and social critic who created some of the world's best-known fictional characters.
English novelist known primarily for her six major novels, which interpret, critique, and comment upon the British landed gentry.
American writer, humorist, entrepreneur, publisher, and lecturer.
Known for 'The Adventures of Tom Sawyer' and 'Adventures of Huckleberry Finn'.
American novelist, short-story writer, and journalist.
Known for his sparse, direct prose style.
American writer and Nobel Prize laureate.
Known for his modernist style and complex narratives.
English writer considered one of the most important modernist 20th-century authors.
An English poet, essayist, publisher, playwright, and literary critic.
A central figure in English-language Modernism.
English writer, poet, philologist, and university professor.
Author of 'The Hobbit' and 'The Lord of the Rings'.
English novelist and essayist.
Wrote 'Nineteen Eighty-Four' and 'Animal Farm'.
A family of English writers, including Charlotte, Emily, and Anne.
Wrote 'Jane Eyre' and 'Wuthering Heights'.
A Russian writer regarded as one of the greatest authors of all time.
Known for 'War and Peace'.
A Russian novelist, philosopher, and short story writer.
Known for 'Crime and Punishment'.
A Greek poet who is traditionally the author of the epic poems 'The Iliad' and 'The Odyssey'.
An ancient Roman poet of the Augustan period.
Wrote the epic poem 'The Aeneid'.
An Italian poet of the Late Middle Ages.
Known for his epic poem 'The Divine Comedy'.
An Irish novelist and poet.
Considered one of the most influential writers in the modernist avant-garde.
Mark Twain's real name was Samuel Clemens.
Known for his use of regional dialect in his writing.
A French novelist, critic, and essayist.
Wrote 'In Search of Lost Time'.
An American poet, novelist, and short story writer.
Wrote 'The Bell Jar'.
A Russian playwright and short-story writer.
Considered one of the greatest writers of short fiction in history.
A British writer and physician.
Creator of Sherlock Holmes.
A famous novel by Charlotte Bronte.
The protagonist is an orphan who becomes a governess.
A dystopian social science fiction novel by George Orwell.
Features the character Big Brother.
A novel by F. Scott Fitzgerald.
Explores themes of decadence, idealism, and social upheaval.
A novel by Herman Melville.
A sailor's obsessive quest for a giant whale.
A play by William Shakespeare.
The protagonist seeks revenge for his father's murder.
An ancient Greek epic poem by Homer.
Details the journey of a king trying to get home after the Trojan War.
A novel by Harper Lee.
Deals with racial inequality in the American South.
A romantic novel by Jane Austen.
Follows the character Elizabeth Bennet.
A satirical novella by George Orwell.
An allegory of the Russian Revolution.
A fantasy novel by J.R.R. Tolkien.
Follows the character Bilbo Baggins.
A novel by Leo Tolstoy.
Considered a central work of world literature.
A novel by Mary Shelley.
Tells the story of a scientist who creates a grotesque creature.
An ancient Greek epic poem by Homer.
Set during the Trojan War.
A Latin epic poem written by Virgil.
Tells the legendary story of Aeneas.
A novel by Fyodor Dostoevsky.
Focuses on the moral dilemmas of an impoverished student.
An epic poem by Dante Alighieri.
Describes a journey through Hell, Purgatory, and Paradise.
A collection of 24 stories written by Geoffrey Chaucer.
Tells the story of a group of pilgrims.
An 1897 novel by Bram Stoker.
Introduced the character of Count Dracula.
A dystopian novel by Lois Lowry.
About a boy who is selected to be the Receiver of Memory.
A narrative poem by Edgar Allan Poe.
Known for its musicality and supernatural atmosphere.
A novel by Sylvia Plath.
A semi-autobiographical work about a young woman's mental illness.
A novel by J.D. Salinger.
Narrated by a teenager named Holden Caulfield.
A novel by Emily Bronte.
Features the characters Heathcliff and Catherine.
English novelist known for 'Pride and Prejudice'.
Widely regarded as the greatest writer in the English language.
A Russian novelist who wrote 'Crime and Punishment'.
English novelist known for 'A Tale of Two Cities' and 'Oliver Twist'.
An Irish poet and playwright.
Known for 'The Picture of Dorian Gray'.
An American writer, poet, and literary critic.
Known for his dark and mysterious stories.
American writer and humorist.
Wrote about the adventures of Tom Sawyer.
American novelist who wrote 'Moby-Dick'.
English writer and creator of Middle-earth.
English writer known for her detective novels and short story collections.
An English novelist who used a male pen name.
Wrote 'Middlemarch'.
An English poet, painter, and printmaker.
Known for 'Songs of Innocence and of Experience'.
